Labour’s strained relations with business were under the spotlight again on Wednesday after Ed Balls, shadow chancellor, struggled to name a big business backer of Labour, eventually coming up with “Bill”.

Mr Balls joked that his memory lapse on BBC’s Newsnight programme was “an age thing” and that he had intended to identify Bill Thomas, a non-executive director of the Co-operative Bank, who ran Labour’s small business task force.

But Mr Balls’ inability to reel off a list of big Labour supporters in the City or in boardrooms was a reminder of how far the party’s business base has been eroded in recent years, including under the leadership of Ed Miliband.

Although no FTSE 100 bosses supported Tony Blair before he become prime minister in 1997, by the 2005 election he had a roster of 63 backers from banking, leisure, media, engineering and other sectors prepared to sign a letter to the Financial Times endorsing his policies.

The letter applauded Labour for presiding over “unprecedented” economic stability and growth and fostering an entrepreneurial society: a sign of New Labour’s success in wooing corporate Britain.

Among the signatories then were Charles Allen, chief executive of ITV; Sir Ronald Cohen, executive chairman of the venture capital group Apax Partners; Lord Hollick of United Business Media; Sir Gerry Robinson, chairman of Allied Domecq, and Sir Alan Sugar, chairman of Amstrad.

Mr Balls was asked on Newsnight to name some prominent Labour business backers and he replied: “Well, erm, Bill. The former chief executive of EDS who I was just talking to.”

Pressed on who this was, Mr Balls said he was “a big supporter” but then admitted: “It has just gone from my head, which is a bit annoying at this time of night.” Labour officials said it was a simple human error.

Mr Balls has attempted to win support in the City and business for Labour, but pro-business figures in the shadow cabinet, including Chuka Umunna, shadow business secretary, often feel their efforts are undercut by the tone towards business used by Mr Miliband.

Digby Jones, a former minister in the last Labour government, said Mr Balls’ inability to name business supporters was a symptom of “a bigger problem” and that naming Mr Thomas as a big backer was “scraping the barrel”.

“Business wants the mood music of this nation to be in favour of creating wealth,” Lord Jones told the BBC’s Today programme. “It’s about this concept that you’re not hearing from Ed Miliband — or Ed Balls — that creating wealth is a good thing.”

Mr Balls has insisted that Labour is a centrist and pro-business party. Mr Miliband also points out that he would not put Britain’s EU membership in jeopardy, a cause of considerable business uncertainty, by holding a referendum on Britain leaving.
title: Business pressure on UK Labour party increases
